QST de W1AW
ARRL Bulletin 19 ARLB019
From ARRL Headquarters
Newington CT October 24, 2017
To all radio amateurs
SB QST ARL ARLB019
ARLB019 Communications Interoperability Training with Amateur Radio Community Set
Elements of the US Department of Defense (DOD) will conduct a "communications interoperability" training exercise November 4-6, once again simulating a "very bad day" scenario. Amateur Radio and MARS organizations will take part.
"This exercise will begin with a notional massive coronal mass ejection event which will impact the national power grid as well as all forms of traditional communication, including landline telephone, cellphone, satellite, and Internet connectivity," Army MARS Program Manager Paul English, WD8DBY, explained in an announcement.
During the exercise, a designated DOD Headquarters entity will request county-by-county status reports for the 3,143 US counties and county equivalents, in order to gain situational awareness and to determine the extent of impact of the scenario. Army and Air Force MARS organizations will work in conjunction with the Amateur Radio community, primarily on the 60-meter interoperability channels as well as on HF NVIS frequencies and local VHF and UHF, non-Internet linked Amateur Radio repeaters.
Again this year, a military station on the east coast and the Fort Huachuca, Arizona, HF station will conduct a high-power broadcast on 60-meter channel 1 (5330.5 kHz) on Sunday from 0300 to 0315 UTC (Saturday evening).
New this year will be an informational broadcast on Sunday, on 13483.5 kHz USB from 1600 to 1615 UTC (Sunday morning). Amateur Radio operators should monitor these broadcasts for more information about the exercise and how they can participate in this communications exercise, English said.
"We want to continue building on the outstanding cooperative working relationship with the ARRL and the Amateur Radio community," English said. "We want to expand the use of the 60-meter interop channels between the military and amateur community for emergency communications, and we hope the Amateur Radio community will give us some good feedback on the use of both the 5-MHz interop and the new 13-MHz broadcast channels as a means of information dissemination during a very bad day scenario."
Contact Paul English for more information or questions about this exercise via email at: mars.exercises@gmail.com.
NNNN

MARS Members give Presentation to Retired AF Personnel
Last week, Army and AF MARS members traveled to the Blue Skies Village west of San Antonio, TX to give a MARS presentation to retired AF personnel. Before the presentation, the MARS personnel were treated to lunch with the club members. Following the presentations, Rodney Warner gave a demonstration from his mobile HF setup connecting via Automatic Link Establishment with Fort Huachuca, AZ.
MARS members participating ...in this visit were Rodney Warner, Ernest Reich, and Don Bragg.
(photos courtesy Blue Skies club members)

MARS Members in Region 4 Support Hurricane Irma Response while MARS Members in Region 7 Support Iowa Communications Exercise "Stable Mercury"
MARS members in Region 4 are continuing to monitor the Hurricane Watch Net and posting relevant disaster situational awareness information to the Hurricane Irma response portal on the All Partner Access Network. MARS members as well as a military HF station on the east coast are also cooperating with FEMA to support Navy ships designat...ed to respond to Irma by conducting radio checks on the 60 meter interoperability channels. DHS SHARES and W1AW are also participating in these radio check preparations.
On Friday 8 September, ARRL published "ARLB017 Operating procedures During Hurricane Irma" reminding amateur radio operators to operate in such a manner to ensure that Federal government station, as primary users, can have immediate use of any 60 meter channel during these response operations.
Meanwhile, at Camp Dodge located in Johnston, IA, MARS members from Region 7 were supporting a communications interoperablity exercise that included the Iowa National Guard, the 71st Civil Support Team, the Iowa Mobile Emergency Operations Center, Coast Guard Auxiliary Division 33, Polk County Emergency Management, Jasper County emergency Management, Polk County ARES, and Story County ARES. The exercise kicked off with an HF training presentation which included an overview of how MARS interfaces between DOD and the amateur radio community and the DHS SHARES HF network. Also discussed were techniques for determining HF propagation using a variety of available tools. The HF portion of this exercise focused on using the 5 MHz interop channels to send ICS 213 messages via voice procedures. Military and auxiliary units also trained on using the MARS phone patch net.
A special thanks to the MARS members who I threw into the mix to serve as observers/controllers/troubleshooters to interface with the amateur radio operators as well as the various military units at five separate incident command posts spread across Camp Dodge.
MARS members who supported this exercise were: Mike Howard, Dennis Gabler, Keith Carpenter, Joe Galloway, Tom Conrey, and Isaac Helgins. Isaac, by the way, just completed his training and removed his /T last week and was in the mix this week helping with the training. I also want to thank the MARS operators from the Region who helped monitor the 5 MHz and SHARES channels to accept the ICS 213 messages.
Thanks to everyone for your continued support...Hurricane Harvey two weeks ago, Hurricane Irma and Exercise Stable Mercury this week but also keep your eye on Hurricane Jose closely following Irma...almost a category 4 storm!
Paul English
Chief Army MARS

MARS Teams Stand down in Region 6 from Harvey while MARS personnel in Region 4 are put on alert for Irma!
Deployed MARS teams supporting TX National Guard will stand down and return home Tuesday 5 Sept. Many thanks to these teams for their support to Hurricane Harvey response operations...a job well done!
This morning, I sent a warning order to MARS Region 4 to be prepared to monitor the Hurricane Watch Net as Hurricane Irma ramps up to a category 4 storm bearing down on the... US Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. I requested the Region 4 leadership link up with MARS members in Puerto Rico and to make contact with the National Guard in USVI.
Additionally, I am coordinating with FEMA on the potential use of the 60 Meter interop channels by Navy ships being identified to respond to Irma.
The Hurricane Watch Net will activate on Tuesday 5 Sep at 1800Z.
v/r
Paul
Chief Army MARS

MARS Support to Hurricane Harvey Continues...
Here's the update I sent to the 7th Theater Signal Command and the Network Enterprise Technology Command Headquarters:
*****...
Deployed HF teams are now located in Katy and Beaumont, TX supporting TX Guard command posts. Two HF teams remain providing support to the TX Guard joint Operations Center and Communications Coordination Group both located on Camp Mabry Austin, TX. All deployed personnel are on TX Guard orders.
Deployed TX Guard Forces are now using the MARS VHF repeater located in Houston to support response operations. The MARS VHF repeater is located on one of the Houston Transtar towers with the antenna mounted at approximately 200 feet; the repeater operates on NETCOM frequency assignments.
The TX Guard J6 requested we begin providing county status reports from around the affected areas. Our members are receiving these reports from local amateur radio operators as well as from members who live in the affected area. These reports are provided to the Joint Operations Center for situational awareness.
We are collecting lessons learned from this response and will schedule an after action review with the TX Guard and deployed members upon redeployment, recovery, and refit.
*****
v/r
Paul
Chief, Army MARS

MARS Teams activated to support TX Army National Guard Response to Hurricane Harvey
In accordance with a standing request for HF support from the TX Army National Guard to the Army's Network Enterprise Technology Command, up to four Army MARS HF teams will be activated to provide HF communications to designated TX National Guard units prepositioning for response to Hurricane Harvey.
MARS members being activated for this mission, regularly train with the TX Guard and use HF ...go kits provided by the Guard. These MARS members will be placed on orders supporting the Guard...for liability and accountability reasons, there will be no "self-deploying" MARS members.
Regular on-air training in FEMA Region 6 is suspended until the support to the TX Guard is no longer needed.
MARS members not directly supporting this deployment are encouraged to provide support via your local ARES, RACES or the Hurricane Watch Net and SATERN activities.
English
Chief Army MARS

Support to DHS "JamEx"
Recently, Army MARS member Mike Itnyre, supported the Department of Homeland Security First Responder jamming exercise, called "JamEx," which was held at the Idaho National Lab. Mike deployed to JamEx as a member of the LA County Sheriff's AuxCom unit (not as a MARS member). While at JamEx, a DHS employee approached Mike to see if he would assist as a data collector when the contracted data collector walked off the job. Mike spent the next few days s...erving as a DHS observer/data collector during the various RF jamming scenarios.
In order to minimize possible jamming affects outside of the exercise scenario, the JamEx ran from ~1800 until 0600 hrs for several days. Mike reported that in addition to the overnight testing events, there were also closely scheduled times for when participants were allowed to enter and depart the facility which made for very long days.
Mike commented that while there were very long days and working the "midnight shift," he was extremely pleased to have been a part of DHS JamEx for a second year. Mike's story highlights the fact that our members find themselves in some very interesting, challenging and exciting times as MARS members even when they are not serving in a MARS capacity.
Well done Mike!
(photo courtesy Mike Itnyre)

What will you be doing for the 21 Aug 2017 Solar Eclipse?
https://eclipse2017.nasa.gov
Will you be on the air taking part in the HamSci experiments?
...
Will you participate in the ARRL Eclipse QSO Party?
Will you be monitoring WWV, WWVB, or the AM bands listening for changes in propagation?
West Point Cadets will be on the air participating in the Eclipse QSO party.
SATERN HF nets may be activating.
David McGinnis and I, along with several MARS members from Region 8 and other regions will be in Denver, CO training HF communications during a NORTHCOM sponsored communications interoperablity exercise called Vital Connections. Participating in this exercise will be elements of the Joint Communications Support Element (JCSE) from MacDill AFB, FL; Civil Air Patrol, NORTHCOM deployable comms trailer, US Coast Guard, Colorado National Guard, DHS SHARES, state, county, and local first responders and AUXCOM entities including MARS, SATERN, and amateur radio operators.
Finally, if you are going to watch the eclipse, make sure you maintain eye-safety...regular sunglasses will not protect your eyes.
Happy eclipsing everyone!
Paul
Chief Army MARS

US Army North Trains in New Mexico
Recently elements of the US Army North G6 trained at Kirkland Air Force Base, New Mexico as part of exercise Vigilant Guard. Using commercial emergency response vehicles (ERV), the Army North personnel are able to rapily establish reachback communications for on-site leadership. Pictured is the smaller ERV which provides both internet and telephone connectivity via the roof top mounted Ku satellite dish. The ERV is also equipped with a VRC-104 Harris HF radio which Army North personnel used to make radio calls to the Fort Huachuca HF Gateway.
(photos and information courtesy Matt Hopper)

US Military Academy at West Point is on the Air!
West Point's Military Auxiliary Radio System (MARS) station and Cadet Amateur Radio Club station W2KGY are now fully operational following the successful installation of a folded dipole antenna provided by US NORTHCOM J6.
The antenna installation team included: CPT (P) Mathew Sherburne, COL Shay, Roy Spells, SGM Copeleitti, Joe DeLorenzo, DJ Phillips, William Corp, CPT Luke Reece, SPC Colin Wallace and Sean and Deborah Flynn.... DJ Phillips traveled all the way from Fort Drum in order to help and will take the experience back to Fort Drum in order to help build a US Army MARS station on post. CPT Reece and SPC Wallace from 10th Mountain Division used this opportunity to gain valuable knolwedge for setting up HF antennas for his unit.
The first radio contact was made with a mobile amateur radio station, VE3REJ in Ontario, Canada immediately followed by a contact with amateur radio station WB5TJK in southern Mississippi. West Point also made contact with the Army MARS headquarters station at Fort Huachuca, Arizona.
The successful activation of the station now means West Point has a world-wide communications capability that does not require any infrastucture to include satellite communications. The cadets are looking forward to operating the station during the Canadian sponsored Noble Skywave HF radio exercise this fall as well as participating in NORTHCOM's homeland defense exercises called Vital Connections.
(article and photos courtesy of CPT (P) Sherburne)

NOAA NWS National Hurricane Center added 2 new photos.
· 19 June ·
NHC is issuing advisories on Potential Tropical Cyclone Three, located over the Gulf of Mexico about 305 miles (490 km) south of the mouth of the Mississippi Ri...ver. A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the Louisiana coastline from Intracoastal City to the Mouth of the Pearl River, and a Tropical Storm Watch is in effect from west of Intracoastal City to High Island. On the forecast track, the disturbance will move toward the Louisiana coast on Tuesday and Wednesday.
Tropical storm conditions are expected to first reach the coast within the warning area on Tuesday. Tropical storm conditions are possible in the watch area on Wednesday. Total rain accumulations of 4 to 8 inches with isolated maximum amounts of 10 inches over southeastern Louisiana, southern Mississippi and Alabama, and the western Florida Panhandle through Wednesday evening.
Maximum sustained winds are near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. Some slight strengthening is possible before the system reaches the coast.
Get the latest on this system at http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/#THREE

A Successful Hamvention 2017 Concludes
From 19-21 May, the annual Hamvention took place at its new home at the Greene County Fairgrounds in Xenia, Ohio. Again this year, the Army and Air Force MARS team was joined by members from the DHS SHARES program. New for this year, Malcolm Kyser, Director of Communications for the Civil Air Patrol joined the team at Hamvention. Mark Jensen from US Northern Command spent time with the team.
Ross Merlin, DHS SHARES Program Manager, ta...lked about the DHS SHARES program Friday morning during the opening Hamvention forum. Ross’ presentation can be viewed at the below URL:
https://connect.apan.org/p80jelc5f6a/
Immediately following the SHARES forum, Paul English and Dave Stapchuk gave presentations at the MARS forum. Also presenting were David McGinnis, NETCOM HF Operations Officer and Richard Duncan, MARS Joint Phone Patch net manager. During the forum, Paul English recognized Kent Dickinson for his service as the former Region 7 Director. Paul English also announced that effective Friday 19 May, he assumed responsibility as Chief Army MARS. There were 127 in-person attendees and 24 who watched the live stream. The MARS forum can be viewed at URL:
https://connect.apan.org/p6hy7ywbtii/
Both MARS Chiefs as well as DHS SHARES, CAP and NORTHCOM participated in the 2d annual ARRL Public Service Communications forum Saturday afternoon. This forum can be viewed at:
https://connect.apan.org/p2o27u4hglg/
Army MARS also recorded the SATERN forum presentation which can be viewed at URL:
https://connect.apan.org/p7ab3gmx9o5/
At the MARS booth, we had 36 Army members stop by from: MO, NJ, OH, PA, AZ, MD, GA, TN, CO, MN, WI, VA, KY, NC, IA, IL, NC, MI, NY and FL. Thanks to all that stopped by to say hi!
Hamvention wouldn’t be Hamvention without a little rain…this year was no disappointment as it rained EVERYDAY! Fortunately, that didn’t dampen the enthusiasm of the attendees.
We would like to thank the hard-working volunteers from the Dayton Amateur Radio Association for the outstanding job they did relocating Hamvention from Hara Arena to the Greene County Fairgrounds. This team of dedicated personnel successfully pulled off a monumental task and made it look easy…thanks DARA!

US Military Academy at West Point Trains in QRPX
CPT(P) Sherburne and Cadet-in-Charge: Cadet Morton were joined by Cadets Bowers, Wyrsch, Cobb, Shorkey-Chacon, and Hanna operating West Point’s US Army Military Auxiliary Radio System (MARS) station on Saturday 1 April during the US Army NETCOM sponsored QRPX 2017 HF radio exercise held 30 March to 1 April.
Setting up nothing more than a simple military dipole antenna in the trees near the top of the West Point ski slope, the ...cadets were able to make HF radio contacts as far away as Texas (1,400 miles) and Florida (1,000 miles). The highlight of the event was making HF radio contact with the US Army Reconnaissance School located in Fort Benning, GA (840 miles).
The mission of this annual exercise is to, “Practice and instruct high frequency radio foundations such as: selection of antennas, selection of radio frequencies, “hand jamming” and using RPA software, program fixed frequency and ALE nets, use TAC-CHAT or other terminal software, and exchange low volume information in a cyber denied environment. Through establishing radio contacts on established calling frequencies, units train basic HF radio tasks to enhance proficiency.”
CPT(P) Sherburne, a Cyber Officer, taught the cadets about polyalphabetic substitution ciphers and how the QRPX 2017 exercise employed a version of this type of cipher in order to authenticate participating stations and to encrypt our military grid coordinate and decrypt the military grid coordinates of other stations. CPT(P) Sherburne explained why such a basic cipher is used in a scenario in which computers may no longer function and potential weaknesses if this cipher is not used properly such as falling victim to letter-frequency analysis attacks.
The cadets operated a Harris RF-5022 HF radio that dates back to 1985.
Congratulations to the West Point Military Academy team for taking part in this training event.
(Story and Photos courtesy CPT Sherburne)

A Blast from the Past ~1960/70s
HQs was recently contacted by the daughter of a former MARS member who provided some unique historical documents about her father's time serving in MARS. While doing some additional research, she also provided the following vignette:
*****...
An article surfaced that was written in 1968 and I have included it for you to read. Our dad, Jessie LeJune, was the Director of the MARS Project on Base at Fort Polk.
Five years later, in May of 1973, he was recognized and awarded for his Outstanding Service to the MARS Radio Station, AA5WBN, Post Signal Office, by the Department of The Army, Major General, Thomas M. Rienzi, Assistant Chief of Staff for Communications-Electronics, Washington, DC. (Attached - 3 pages)
We have the original picture that was in the Shreveport Times, but wanted the article. So I put a friend who lives in Shreveport, LA on a mission to get a copy. What happened along the way for my friend changed her in a small way. After several weeks of going through public library archives, she was finally sent to the main library, where she met a library employee, whom she described as a grumpy old man with a bad attitude. After much research, the 1968 article was found and off he went to make her a copy. Upon returning, he stood before her with tears in his eyes and softly spoke, "Do you know this man?" And she responded, "Yes, I am friends with his daughter and she asked me to get her a copy of the article."
Let me just stop at this point and tell you that up until then he had not taken the time to read the caption under the picture......
He softly spoke saying, "One of those men that called home was me. Please thank him for his service."
Now years later, dad's small part that he played in the MARS project is still changing lives. Our dad will turn 86 on March 30. What a great service to our country he was and we are just now finding out.
*****
Thanks to Donna LeJune for sharing this bit of MARS history with us!

Fort Hood Soldiers Train on HF Communications
On Thursday 30 March, Soldiers from the 1st Cavalry Division spent the morning learning the basics of HF communication including HF propagation, different types of HF antennas and various tools available to them for choosing and predicting the best HF frequency for communications. This training was followed by hands-on practical exercises with programming the PRC-150 radio, setting up various military HF antennas and making singl...e channel radio checks with MARS members around Texas. Following the single channel radio checks, the Soldiers did some training with Automatic Link Establishment (ALE) by doing some Link Quality Analysis checks with other ALE stations and testing the ACP 193 phone patch capability.
Thanks to all the MARS members around the state of Texas who guarded the frequencies waiting for the Soldiers to come on the air.

DOD Comex 17-1 Concludes
The quarterly DOD comex 17-1 wrapped up today. This comex was a technical exercise focused on allowing the Region and State leadership to train with the individual MARS member to ensure they loaded the new encryption keys, to continue the roll out of the new on-line encryption program, and to practice submitting various reports during a multi-day exercise.
This comex began on Saturday 25 Feb and was designed to practice what we call sustained netwo...rk operations...essentially minimizing how much time members spend on the air, thereby not burning out our volunteers and also conserving electrical power and backup power capablities while still passing needed information during a time of notional wide-spread crisis.
Dave Stapchuk and I appreciate all MARS members who trained during this exercise...well done everyone!
Paul English
Army MARS Program Manager

West Point Military Academy Radio Station Update
On Saturday, 25 February 2017, CPT(P) Matthew Sherburne – KF4WZB, Cadet Jonathan Morton – KE8EBT, and Cadet Paul Shorkey-Chacon – KC3HBB installed new floor tiling in the W2KGY Ground Station located at West Point. They also brought two radios out of storage: the Icom IC-781 HF radio and the Yaesu FT-736 VHF/UHF radio; radios that were top-of-the-line in the late ‘80s. These radios were placed in storage due to building renova...tions when the W2KGY Ground Station was taken offline for five years and counting. Cadets used the Yaesu FT-736 to talk directly with COL McArthur – USMA ‘73 from the International Space Station back in January 2006.
The IC-781 HF radio will be modified so that it will also function on US Army MARS frequencies so that W2KGY can participate in MARS and USNORTHCOM communications exercises. These exercises require the usage of a computer connected to the radio in order to encrypt and decrypt digital communications. W2KGY is still working on procuring much needed IT equipment that includes desktop computers and monitors to support this US Army MARS requirement in order to participate. Once the station is online, West Point will have an emergency HF radio communications capability should all satellite, cellular, and landline communications go down. This very scenario is rehearsed through USNORTHCOM’s VITAL CONNECTION exercises.
The West Point station is still inoperable as we await a US Army Corps of Engineers design and engineer assessment on the installation of a satellite antenna array and HF antenna tower on the roof of Bartlett Hall. Until then, the Ground Station is on static display with Cadets unable to make radio contact with anyone from this room.
A group of amateur radio operators from Tennessee is conducting a fundraiser so that W2KGY can once again lead the pack and stay innovative with the latest state-of-the-art software defined radio – the Flex-6700. Cadets will experience digital signal processing and other advancements in software defined radio technologies. W2KGY has so far received $1.9k in donations of the Flex-6700 $10k price tag.
(story and photos courtesy CPT promotable Sherburne)

DOD Commex 16-4 Concludes
On Sunday 30 Oct, MARS members simulated a nation-wide communications outage and self activated to provide contingency communications support to the Department of Defense. After notionally assessing the situation, the DOD coordinated to activate a high power HF broadcast on 60 meters from an east coast military station as well as the Fort Huachuca HF Gateway station.
This broadcast, coordinated with FEMA, simulated providing information to the ama...teur radio community as well as shortwave listeners throughout the United States. These broadcasts were received by more than 450 amateur radio, military, and shortwave listeners. Following the 60 meter broadcast, MARS personnel were tasked to make contact with amateur radio operators and collect county status information.
Throughout the remainder of the 48 hour exercise, MARS members continued to make contact with amateur radio operators throughout the US as well as acting on other tasks in support of the DOD headquarters.
Headquarters wants to thank all MARS members, both Air Force and Army for your outstanding support during this exercise. We also appreciate and thank the many amateur radio operators who supported this cooperative effort.
Well done to all!

High Power Broadcast on 60 Meters a huge Success!
On 31 Oct from 0300-0400 Hrs Zulu, a military station on the east coast and the Fort Huachcua HF Gateway station broadcast a voice message on 5330.5 KHz upper sideband to the amateur radio and shortwave listening community. The purpose of this broadcast was to promote the use of the 60 meter channels for interoperablity between military and amateur radio stations. Stations who successfully received the broadcast were request...ed to submit a reception report. Approximatley 450 reports have been received.
Pictured is David McGinnis running a Barrett 2050 and a Tokyo High Power 1Kw amp feeding a 5-30 MHz log periodic antenna mounted at 90 feet. For each broadcast, Fort Huachuca oriented their log antenna to different locations to maximize reception.
(photo courtesy Ed Collins)

Army MARS Team Places Second in Canadian International Communications Competition
On 26 and 27 October, 2016, the Canadian Armed Forces held an international communications competition involving Active Duty, Reserves, National Guard and Military Auxiliary communications personnel from Canada, England, Australia, New Zealand and the United States. This is the fourth year the Canadian military hosted this international competition which challenges participants to make as many ...contacts as possible during the exercise period on either single sideband voice or using Automatic Link Establishment (ALE).
This year a MARS team from Region 5, Ohio, placed second overall in the competition. The team consisted of David Hudelson, George Riedel, Bob Evans, Don Knuckles, Allen Mytyk, Robb Landon, and Tony Spiegel.
Dave Hudelson wrote about the Canadian sponsored competition: “First and foremost it was a tremendous team effort. Our team consisted of members with more than 50 years of MARS service to barely one year of service, with roots in all three branches, but we took off our stripes and pulled together to accomplish the mission.
I want to offer a special thanks to Bob Evans, Don Knuckles, and George Riedel who were real workhorses from start to finish.
In the end we logged 56 contacts to 36 different stations, 22 of them in Canada. The longest was 2,000 miles and the shortest 140 miles, with the middle 60% between 340 and 820 miles. Contacts were made on 13 different frequencies from 2.6 to 20 MHz. During the final targeted-pair phase, one-shot one-kill in the midst of pileups was an impressive feat to witness. All of it a testament to well-tuned antennas, solid knowledge of propagation, and the METL training we perform on every Region V network.
Finally, our hats go off to our Canadian hosts. The exercise went off without a major hitch despite a flurry of G2 solar storms prior to and during the exercise. We also noted the professionalism and graciousness of both military and CFARS stations alike. Without a call sign to give their affiliation away it would be hard to tell one from the other. We are already looking forward to next October.”
The competition organizers published the top three results:
SSB division
1st place:
51 pts- Canadian Team from Valcatier Canada on a training exercise at Fort Bliss, TX
2nd place:
41 pts – Canadian Team from Québec, Canada
3rd place:
40 pts – Canadian 33 Sigs from Montreal, Canada
ALE division
1st place:
59 pts – Canadian Team from Valcartier, Canada
2nd place:
35 pts – MARS Team from Ohio
3rd place:
30 pts – Canadian team from Acton, Canada
On behalf of Ex Noble Skywave staff, congratulations to the winners and all participants!!!
Capt Dargan and MWO Dénommée
Headquarters Army MARS also thanks everyone who participated in this year’s Exercise Noble Skywave and offer a special thanks to the Canadian Military for once again sponsoring this exercise. We look forward to next year!

Army and AF MARS Members Train in Minnesota
October 15, 2016, twelve MARS members met at the Minneapolis Emergency Operations Training Facility, at Minneapolis, MN to conduct face-to-face technical training. Air Force MARS members Don Heppelmen and Reginald Cass coordinated the training event hosted by Region 5 Air Force MARS.
Mark Allen, Air Force MARS National Operations and Frequency Manager presented an enthralling video on the highly successful Phone Patch Network. This ...network is led by AF MARS and supported by Army MARS members to provide phone patch support for US military aircraft.
Brad Peters, Air Force MARS Minnesota MARS Director, spoke to the group about upcoming changes to be expected and encouraged stations to work together and practice.
Members were given an updated version of the “Digital Road Show” presented by Jodie Rouse, Region 7 Army MARS Missouri Director. Participants installed MARS software updates and every member had the opportunity to troubleshoot their station equipment and familiarize themselves with the changes. During a working lunch, members honed their skills in writing and sending messages, using specially designed software for automated messages, encryption and military standard data modems.
Don Heppelmann commented that the Region 5 MARS Conference was a great place to learn key information to better support our customer. Don said that he came away with high confidence to offer the support needed for the assigned tasks.
Mark Allen presented certificates of Appreciation to Jodie Rouse, Don Heppelmann, and Reginald Cass for their contributions and efforts to make the meeting possible.
Member Bob Bohner remarked: “This was useful, I had planned to drop out of AFMARS in frustration. What I learned encouraged me. I am now back on the Ham air and am trying for my first check-in in several months."
Member Vince Lynch, commented, “I was very encouraged on being a member of the Air Force MARS. I was taught how to write MARS message and use the proper Routing Indicator. On my own, I tried to figure out how to write a message and too many parts of the message were unclear. The meeting was a great opportunity to share stories and meet other MARS members.”
Mark Allen, summed up the event by saying, "Thanks to all who arranged, sponsored and attended the Minnesota State meeting and Digital Roadshow Training exercise. This is another example of how members reach out and help members achieve the MARS mission goals. A special thanks to Jodie Rouse, Army MARS, who was the primary instructor. I was informed at this gathering that we get stations ready to accept our digital mission one station at a time. This was accomplished for a great group. We each left this meeting better able to perform our mission."
(story courtesy Jodi Rouse)

Military Auxiliary Radio System to Conduct Interoperability Exercise with Amateur Radio Community
From 30 October through 1 November, members of the Military Auxiliary Radio System will be conducting a quarterly Department of Defense Contingency Communications exercise. The purpose of this quarterly exercise is train on our ability to provide communications following a “very bad day” scenario when traditional forms of communications will likely be unavailable. While the si...multaneous loss of all communications nation-wide is not likely, for training purposes, we are assuming there has been a massive nation-wide outage.
One of the objectives of this exercise is to continue the partnership with the amateur radio community to help provide information about local conditions and send this information to the Department of Defense to help understand what is happening around the United States.
During this exercise, we will use 60 meters, local VHF and UHF repeaters as well as HF NVIS amateur radio bands. Our goal is to have a conversation about the local conditions in and around your county. During the conversation, our operators will be asking basic questions such as the status of commercial power, public water systems, and road conditions. These will be person to person conversations…you don’t need to use any digital modes or know any special messaging formats.
To kick off this exercise, we are encouraging the amateur radio community to monitor 5,330.5KHz from 0300-0400 Hrs Zulu on 31 October. During this hour, we will be doing a high power voice broadcast from a military station on the east coast and alternate with a voice broadcast from the west coast. Amateur radio operators are encouraged to submit a reception report as indicated in the voice broadcast.
For the remainder of the exercise, MARS personnel will be calling for amateur radio operators on the 60 meter channels as well as using already established amateur radio nets on HF NVIS and VHF/UHF repeaters.
Amateur radio operators are also invited to attend the ARRL webinar scheduled for 25 Oct at 2000 hrs eastern time where Dave Stapchuk, Chief AF MARS, and the Army MARS Program Manager will give a presentation about the MARS program. Please register for the webinar at:
https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/regist…/4300481724544982273
If you have further questions about this exercise, please email: mars.exercises@gmail.com .

Hurricane Watch Net
· 2 October 2016 ·
(Update: Sunday, October 2, 2016 3:30 PM EDT – 1930 UTC)
The Hurricane Watch Net will be activating today @ 5:00 PM EDT – 2100 UTC on our primary net frequency ...of 14.325 MHz. Once activated, the net will remain in continuous operation until further notice. We plan to operate 14.325 MHz by day and 7.268 MHz by night. If propagation dictates, we will operate both frequencies at the same time.
Matthew is a very large and dangerous hurricane. It is forecast to produce total rain accumulations of 15 to 25 inches over southern Haiti, with possible isolated maximum amounts of 40 inches. Matthew is forecast to produce total rain accumulations of 10 to 20 inches over eastern Jamaica, the Dominican Republic and eastern Cuba, with possible isolated maximum amounts of 25 inches. This rainfall will produce life-threatening flash floods and mud slides.
Matthew is expected to affect Jamaica, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Cuba, the Turks and Caicos, and the Bahamas over the next few days. People along the US East Coast should also keep an eye on Matthew.
As with any net activation, we will be requesting observed ground-truth data from those in the affected area (Wind Speed, Wind Gust, Wind Direction, Barometric Pressure – if available, Rain, Damage, and Storm Surge). If you have measured weather data, that would be of great help. As always, we remind reporting stations to "please" do not report to us the weather information reported by your local media. We are interested ONLY in YOUR personal observations, preferably measured by calibrated instrumentation.
We are available to provide backup communications to official agencies such as Emergency Operations Centers and Red Cross officials in the affected area. We will also be interested to collect and report significant damage assessment data back to FEMA officials stationed in the National Hurricane Center.
For those seeking to pass Health and Welfare traffic, we will respectfully defer this to the SATERN net. They are better equipped and trained for this type of traffic. When active, they operate on 14.265 MHz. Also, you can find them online at www.satern.org.
Please honor our request that you not check in to the net unless specifically requested to do so. We will attempt to handle all communications within the capabilities of our own members. When outside assistance is required, we will welcome your help. Just closely follow the instructions of Net Control.
As a final reminder, please monitor this web site for storm related advisory updates, graphics displays, and other data made available from the National Hurricane Center.
Please, keep those who are in the path of this dangerous hurricane in your thoughts and prayers!
Sincerely,
Bobby Graves – KB5HAV
Net Manager

United States Air Force MARS appoints members to National Staff
The United States Air Force Military Auxiliary Radio System (USAF MARS) has appointed Mark Allen as its National Operations Officer and Gary Mentro as the National Administrative Assistant.
Mark Allen, a longtime volunteer participant in the AF MARS program advances from Division Director to National Operations Officer. Gary Mentro also brings a strong background supporting the AF MARS mission. These staff posito...ns are key to the overall management of the program and its operational mission.
“I look forward to supporting the volunteers of the AF MARS program who in turn support our active duty and reserve elements of the United States military. It is an exciting time in AF MARS with new technology and an influx of new volunteers” Allen said.
Air Force MARS Chief Dave Stapchuk stated, “USAF MARS has seen a number of mission changes since its inception. It remains a vibrant and important resource to the Department of Defense which costs taxpayers virtually nothing. The women and men of this program volunteer many thousands of hours of their time and equipment annually in support of our mission. In conjunction with our MARS partners, we are transitioning into exciting new technology for moving messages globally.
The National staff plays a critical role in seeing that the mission is accomplished. I am truly appreciative of everything our members do, and those members who have stepped into leadership roles in the program are just amazing. I could not accomplish all that needs to be done without their assistance.”
ABOUT MARS
The United States Military Auxiliary Radio System is comprised of both Army and Air Force MARS. AF MARS is headquartered at Scott Air Force Base, IL and is a contingent unit of the 38th Cyberspace Readiness Squadron. Army MARS belongs to the Army Network Enterprise Technology Command headquarterd at Fort Huachuca, AZ.
MARS recruits, trains and licenses amateur radio operators and their stations to provide contingency communications support on behalf of the men and women of the Department of Defense in support of their important and diverse missions whenever, however and wherever required.
